content: I know I read that Lean's type theory+three standard axioms are equivalent, in a meaningful sense, to New Foundations. I think I heard that it was equivalent to ZFC. But I was reading about Grothendieck universes on Wikipedia, and it said they're "loosely" equivalent to strongly inaccessible cardinals: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grothendieck_universe

So I'm wondering if (1) Lean's type theory is strictly stronger than ZFC, because it includes this axiom, (2) Lean's universe system diverges from Grothendieck universes in a way that stops this from applying, or (3) something crazier and more subtle.

It certainly feels like the axiom of universes is a true statement in Lean. But I realize that -- as stated on Wikipedia -- "For every set s, there exists a universe U that contains s" can't exactly be directly stated as a theorem in Lean, because there's no notion of "there exists a universe", that we can then get as a variable and work with. But can always just take Type (u+1) and that feels practically equivalent.
Lean's type theory (+ 3 standard axioms) is equivalent to ZFC + a countable tower of universes.

Great, thanks. I'm pretty sure what happened was I read "ZFC + {there are n inaccessible cardinals | n < Ï‰}" or something similar a year ago, mentally translated this into "ZFC + some set theory nerd stuff I don't understand" (sorry :P ) , and promptly forgot about what came after the + sign. And now I'm trying to learn it better :)
Alex Meiburg has marked this topic as resolved.
